summary: All nine Flatline improvements appear integrated cleanly, FR-9/FR-10 are consistent with existing scope/acceptance gates, and no new truly blocking contradictions or impossible requirements were introduced.

previous_issues_status.original_issue: FR-2 BUTTERFREEZONE hashing was underspecified and brittle (algorithm, normalization, validation reliability)
previous_issues_status.notes: Now specifies SHA-256 plus a structured JSON extraction/canonicalization step (sorted keys, trimmed values, deterministic arrays, UTF-8), excludes the meta block to avoid circularity, and adds a reference implementation + golden test vectors + validate script. This closes the prior verification gap and reduces OS/whitespace brittleness.

previous_issues_status.original_issue: API docs scope/verification risk: too many endpoints to hand-document and keep accurate; missing enforceable contract and validation gate
previous_issues_status.notes: FR-4 is now explicitly constrained to 7 guaranteed-stable endpoints with full examples, while the remaining routes are covered via an auto-extracted route index (method/path/auth/description) and labeled internal/unstable. Smoke-test checklist remains the validation gate, which makes the quick-start verifiable against a local instance.

previous_issues_status.original_issue: Auth ambiguity (JWT vs API keys) could lead to incorrect onboarding steps
previous_issues_status.notes: JWT (ES256 + JWKS) remains the only auth method with operational steps; API keys are explicitly marked Planned with no operational steps. This stays consistent with the quick-start and acceptance criteria.

previous_issues_status.original_issue: Security guidance missing for auth/keys/admin scoping (risk of shipping unsafe docs)
previous_issues_status.notes: FR-4 acceptance criteria now explicitly requires security disclaimers (no private keys in code, dev/prod JWKS separation, rotation expectations, TTL guidance, aud/iss validation, least privilege, admin endpoint scoping). This is additive and does not contradict scope.

previous_issues_status.original_issue: Docs would re-drift without ownership/maintenance triggers and cadence
previous_issues_status.notes: FR-9 introduces a DRI table, concrete update triggers mapped to code paths, doc versioning/errata expectations, and a weekly verification spot-check with a logging location. This is internally consistent with the RTFM validation gate and the overall 'docs-as-product' framing.

previous_issues_status.original_issue: Execution plan lacked sequencing/gates, increasing risk of scope creep and missed launch window
previous_issues_status.notes: FR-10 adds a 5-phase 10-day plan with dependency order and explicit gates aligned to existing acceptance criteria (smoke tests, terraform plan, RTFM, naming grep, hash validation). Circuit breaker is consistent with the earlier staging-only IaC scope (it further reduces work rather than expanding it).

previous_issues_status.original_issue: Cross-repo truth-grounded citations were hard to keep stable and verifiable
previous_issues_status.notes: NFR-1 now adds citation automation via scripts/pin-citations.sh to resolve repo@version:path into commit-SHA permalinks using gh api, while retaining the prohibition on branch links and the grep-based acceptance check. This improves maintainability without weakening the stability requirement.
